M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Complaint for Modification is brought pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, which authorizes the Probate and Family Court to “make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care, custody and maintenance of the minor children” upon a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child and where modification is in the child’s best interests.

M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: To the extent jurisdiction arises or is analogous under M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20, the Court similarly has authority to modify custody and parenting orders concerning a child born to parents who are not married to each other, upon a material and substantial change in circumstances and in accordance with the child’s best interests.

M.G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 215, § 6, this Court has broad equity powers in matters of child custody and welfare, enabling it to fashion orders that protect the minor child’s best interests, including granting one parent final decision‑making authority on particular issues or adjusting parenting schedules.

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 29.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the Middlesex Probate and Family Court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 29; M.G.L. c. 209C, §§ 20, 21; and M.G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this Court issued the current custody and parenting order, the parties and child reside or are present in Middlesex County, and the best interests of the minor child require this Court’s intervention.

M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7\u00a7 20, 21.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the Middlesex Probate and Family Court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 29; M.G.L. c. 209C, §§ 20, 21; and M.G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this Court issued the current custody and parenting order, the parties and child reside or are present in Middlesex County, and the best interests of the minor child require this Court’s intervention.

M.G.L. c. 76, \u00a7\u00a7 1\u20132.proposition: The truancy warnings and documented absences are new circumstances that did not exist at the time of the Existing Judgment and constitute a material change in circumstances under Massachusetts law.

M.G.L. c. 76, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Father’s pattern of keeping Sophia home for non‑medically‑documented “mental health days,” combined with his failure or refusal to ensure attendance at tutoring during his parenting time, is inconsistent with Sophia’s educational needs and contrary to the statutory policy that children attend school regularly.

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: The parties’ joint legal custody arrangement regarding educational decisions presupposes that both parents will act cooperatively and in the minor child’s best interests.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The court directly discusses when joint custody or shared responsibility is appropriate and emphasizes that it requires parents who can cooperate and mutually agree on basic child-rearing issues, including education. It describes joint custody as synonymous with joint decision making and a common desire to promote the children’s best interests, and rejects joint custody here precisely because the parents fundamentally disagree about major child-rearing areas such as education. This aligns with the proposition that a joint legal custody arrangement regarding educational decisions presupposes cooperative, child-focused parental behavior.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “[W]e agree with the trial judge’s observation that in order for joint custody or shared responsibility to work, both parents must be able mutually ‘to agree on the basic issues in child rearing and want to cooperate in making decisions for [their] children.’… Joint custody is synonymous with joint decision making and a common desire to promote the children’s best interests… [T]he parties have basic fundamental differences in the major areas of child rearing, such as health care, religion and education… an order providing joint custody would run contrary to the children’s happiness and welfare.”

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court has made clear that a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting a child’s welfare, coupled with the child’s best interests, is the standard for modifying custody or parenting orders.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).support_reasoning: This case concerns modification of alimony and child support, not custody or parenting-time orders, and it articulates the standard as a material change in circumstances plus consideration of the needs of the children and the parents’ financial circumstances. It does not discuss custody, parenting plans, or a best-interests standard for modifying custody or parenting orders. Using Schuler as authority for the proposition about custody/parenting modification standards therefore misstates its holding and context.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. … In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. … An order for child support may be modified ‘as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.’”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The Appeals Court and Supreme Judicial Court have further recognized that modification is appropriate when the existing order no longer serves the child’s best interests due to material changes arising after the order.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion is an appeal from an initial custody judgment and concerns the adequacy of findings regarding domestic violence in determining the child’s best interests. It does not discuss standards or requirements for postjudgment modification of an existing custody order based on material changes occurring after that order. The court remands for further findings but does not frame this as a modification proceeding or articulate a rule about modification when circumstances change, so it does not support the specific modification proposition stated.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: "Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above."

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The Appeals Court and Supreme Judicial Court have further recognized that modification is appropriate when the existing order no longer serves the child’s best interests due to material changes arising after the order.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The case is not a modification proceeding and expressly declines to apply the substantial-change standard under G.L. c. 209C, § 20, instead treating the matter as an initial custody determination under § 10(a). While the opinion does mention that § 20 governs modifications upon a substantial change in circumstances, it does not hold or analyze that modification is appropriate when an existing order no longer serves the child’s best interests due to post-order material changes. Thus it does not provide substantive authority for the quoted proposition about modification standards in the Appeals Court or SJC.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 209C, § 20, gives the Probate Court jurisdiction to modify an existing judgment for support, custody, or visitation. Such a modification should be made only if ‘a substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child has occurred.’ … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20 … The father’s arguments that G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (c), applies… and that that status cannot be modified in the absence of a ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ (as required by § 20) were not made to the probate judge and are waived.”}

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The Appeals Court and Supreme Judicial Court have further recognized that modification is appropriate when the existing order no longer serves the child’s best interests due to material changes arising after the order.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The decision is a removal / relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a general modification standard case. While there is a procedural posture of a complaint for modification, the SJC’s analysis focuses entirely on the substantive ‘best interests’ standard for removal when there is joint physical custody, not on when a material change in circumstances justifies modification of an existing custody order. The quoted ALI Principles reference ‘substantial change in circumstances’ and modification, but the court does not adopt a general Massachusetts rule that modification is appropriate whenever post‑judgment material changes mean the existing order no longer serves the child’s best interests.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002)… state in pertinent part: ‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances… only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce]… (4)… the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests….’”}

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: The Appeals Court and Supreme Judicial Court have further recognized that modification is appropriate when the existing order no longer serves the child’s best interests due to material changes arising after the order.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: This case is a direct appeal from a divorce judgment addressing initial custody and removal, not a post‑judgment modification proceeding. The opinion does not discuss standards for modifying existing custody or visitation orders based on material changes after entry of the order; instead it articulates the ‘real advantage’ standard and best‑interests analysis for removal at the time of the original divorce judgment. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition about when modification of an existing order is appropriate.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change….”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Appeals Court and Supreme Judicial Court have further recognized that modification is appropriate when the existing order no longer serves the child’s best interests due to material changes arising after the order.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion deals with the standards and findings required for an initial custody award on divorce, focusing on the best interests of the child and proper application of G.L. c. 208, § 31. It does not address modification of an existing custody or support order, nor does it discuss material changes arising after an earlier order. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for when modification is appropriate based on post-judgment changes affecting the child’s best interests.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: "In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied). … This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. … The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child."

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 840\u20138.proposition: The child’s educational stability and academic progress are central components of her best interests.

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404–406 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: A deterioration in a child’s school performance, the emergence of attendance or truancy issues, and the breakdown of parents’ cooperation in making educational decisions all constitute factors that may support a finding of material change and justify modification to safeguard the child’s welfare.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The case is a direct-appeal divorce/custody decision, not a post-judgment modification proceeding, and it does not analyze what constitutes a ‘material change’ warranting modification. While it notes that the parents have fundamental disagreements about education and other child‑rearing issues and that this makes joint custody inappropriate, it does not discuss deterioration in school performance, attendance/truancy problems, or the standard for modifying an existing custody order. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about material change and modification based on educational problems and breakdown of parental cooperation.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “Although the husband had had involvement with the child rearing functions and responsibilities, the judge concluded that because the parties have basic fundamental differences in the major areas of child rearing, such as health care, religion and education, as well as in day-to-day decision making and philosophy of discipline, an order providing joint custody would run contrary to the children’s happiness and welfare. That determination has ample support in the record.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 595\u201.proposition: The Court is charged with placing the child’s welfare above parental disputes.

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: The Court is charged with placing the child’s welfare above parental disputes.
